data.title: James Monroe Trotter (1842-1892)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for James Trotter born 1842 Grand Gulf, Claiborne, Mississippi, United States died 1892 Hyde Park, Boston, Suffolk, Massachusetts, United States including parents + descendants + 2 photos + 1 genealogist comments + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Descendants

Profile last modified 5 Jul 2024 | Created 1 Feb 2018

This page has been accessed 1,152 times.

Biography

Private James Trotter served in the United States Civil War.

Enlisted: 11 Jun 1863

Mustered out: 29 Aug 1865

Side: USA

Regiment(s): Company K, 55th Regiment, Massachusetts Infantry (Colored)

James Trotter is Notable.

James Monroe Trotter was born a slave in 1842 in Grand Gulf, Mississippi[1] to his enslaved mother Letitia and the white man who enslaved his mother, Richard Trotter.[2]

He was a soldier, music historian, U. S. Postal Worker, and the Recorder of Deeds for the District of Columbia.

His son William Monroe Trotter was the founder and editor of the independent African-American newsletter the Boston Guardian and one of the founders of the NAACP.

He attended Gilmore High School in Cincinnati, Ohio founded by Reverend Hiram S. Gilmore in 1844.[2]

He served as a Sergeant Major with the 55th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry during the American Civil War. Sergeant Major was the highest rank attainable to soldiers of color in 1863. He was appointed a Second Lieutenant on 15 July 1865. [3]

His brother-in-law William H. Dupree served as a Lieutenant in Company H of the 55th.

He died in 1892 and is buried in Fairview Cemetery in Boston, Massachusetts.[4]

Sources

↑ 1870, 1880 federal census

↑ 2.0 2.1 Book: Trudeau, Noah Andre. 1949-, Voices of the 55th : Letters from the 55th Massachusetts Volunteers, 1861-1865, database and digital images (Internet Archive : accessed 4 July 2024); citing Dayton, Ohio : Morningside; 1996; page: 139-140.

↑ Record of Service of the 55th Regiment
